;中国科学家表示，他们已经找到了一种使用类似终结者的自媒体的方法治愈液态金属以吸收其他材料并创造出广受欢迎的新型合金，这些合金可以改变航空航天、医学和其他领域。

;

;这一突破可能为发明具有前所未有的硬度、稳定类型的合金铺平道路武汉大学化学与分子科学学院教授付雷领导的团队介绍了其特性和用途。

;

;付告诉《中国科学报》，科学家们的方法简单有效，已发表上周在同行评审期刊《自然》上——最初遭到了怀疑。

;

;“我们两年前发现了这种现象，但很难让人们相信仅仅通过添加液态金属，合成过程[ ”他说。

;

;“即使是《自然》杂志的审稿人在第一次看到手稿时也发现结果“令人难以置信”。”

;

;针对怀疑论者之后，研究人员进行了进一步的实验和分析，并对合成机制进行了更严格的解释，并进行了额外的理论计算。

;

;镓：随着用途的扩大，中国加强了对神奇金属的控制

;

;论文称，他们的结果证明，通过新方法合成的金属在成分或结构上与传统方法没有什么不同，并且不会影响性能。

;

;这一突破将使高熵的创造和制造成为可能。研究人员表示，由五种或更多主要金属元素组成的合金 (HEA) 更容易、更高效。

;

;与传统合金材料相比，HEA 更耐磨损、耐疲劳和耐腐蚀，这使得它们具有显着的优势。在航空航天、医疗设备以及能量转换和存储方面具有潜力。

;

;虽然它们的潜在优势使 HEA 成为近年来研究人员关注的焦点，但实现合金材料合成所需的极高温度已经成为人们关注的焦点。仍然是其发展的障碍。

;

;Fu 表示，合成高熵合金可能具有挑战性，因为不同的金属原子不一定兼容。

;

;“这就像试图制造一个由五个具有不同性质和个性的人组成的有凝聚力的团体。任何分歧都很容易导致团队分裂。”他说。

;

;要通过传统方法实现合成，合金材料必须加热到 2,000 摄氏度（3,632 华氏度），然后快速冷却。

;

;但该论文称，Fu 的团队使用一种名为镓的液态金属作为反应介质和粘合剂，将制备温度降至更易于控制的 650 摄氏度（1,202 华氏度）。

;

;温度仅为 29.8 摄氏度（85.6 华氏度），镓很容易在手掌中变成液体。它对某些金属也具有很强的腐蚀性——一滴水就可以在铝罐上留下一个大洞。

;

;但镓在被操纵后恢复其原始形态的能力使其与形状进行了比较-《终结者》系列电影中的 T-1000 杀手机器人。

;

;Fu 的团队发现，加热放置在液态金属表面上的各种兼容金属会导致结晶 HEA 纳米颗粒的自发生长，这是研究人员的一个过程据该论文报道，实时捕获。

;

;中国团队将液态金属注入“X-rat”中以驱动神经治疗

;

;科学家们还使用镓合成了多种根据该论文，将金属元素转化为 HEA，这超出了传统方法的能力，传统方法仅限于类似元素的调色板。

;

;“所涉及的元素表现出广泛的原子半径（1.24 至 1.97）埃）和熔点（303 至 3683 开尔文）。

;

;据研究人员称，镓的动态混合储层可用于合成具有多种金属元素的 HEA，从而开启了

;

;“对液态金属反应机理和合金化过程的深入研究揭示了其动态演化过程，这也启发了基于液态金属的方法论。”

;数千名狂欢者和桨手冒着酷暑和偶尔的大雨参加国际龙舟比赛时隔四年后，该赛事于周六重返香港维多利亚港。

;

;为期两天的赛事由旅游发展局和香港中国龙舟总会联合举办，吸引了超过 4,000 名来自香港的选手参加。澳大利亚、迪拜、日本、马来西亚、泰国和菲律宾等10个地方。

;

;居民和游客享受了刺激的动作，在长廊上为争夺17个冠军的国内外桨手加油，首次在五项主要比赛中提供现金奖励。每名冠军将获得10,000美元的奖金。

;

;澳大利亚国家队领队Belinda Chung表示，香港的天气与她的国家有很大不同，但球队“享受炎热和潮湿”。< /p>;

;“香港是我们最喜欢参加比赛的地方之一，”她说。 “这给了我们对龙舟运动的不同感受，因为我们都知道龙舟运动来自香港和亚洲。”

;

;端午节回到香港，但参与人数仍低于新冠疫情前的水平mark

;

;继之前在深圳和广州进行过几场比赛后，今年也是波兰首次派出国家队参加比赛。

;

;领队 Joanna Spychala-杜拉表示，天气和14小时的飞行对他们来说是巨大的挑战。但她说，在1.5周的逗留期间，经过几次训练后，她们就适应了。

;

;Peggy To Pui-ki，是当地一支队伍的成员，该队在女子锦标赛的第一轮比赛中获胜早上，她说她对这项赛事的回归感到兴奋，从一月份开始，他们每周训练五天来准备。

;

;“很难形容这种感觉，疫情期间各种比赛都在进行。”取消。我们尝试过训练，但没有目标，但这次比赛规模又回来了，有很多国际队伍，也有更多的居民参与。”

;

;业余队伍也参加了比赛，包括进入总统盾决赛的“S-dragon”。

;

;50岁的赛车手Jason Tse说：“我们都有全职工作，必须挤出时间参加训练晚上，每周至少三到五次……我们对这个结果感到非常高兴。”

;

;沿着尖沙咀海滨的星光大道景点，观众很快就挤满了旁边的有盖看台。李小龙雕像。

;

;许多人在长廊上观看，观察500米赛马场上选手们的实力和团队精神。

;

;李荔枝，27岁来自中国大陆四川省的游客表示，她是第一次观看龙舟比赛。

;

;“这确实满足了我们的好奇心，因为我们的家乡是内陆地区，很少有龙舟比赛， ”她说。

;

;“我很高兴能参加一场真正的大型活动，所有彩色旗帜都排列在长廊上。”

;

;Paul Liu，33 岁从事资讯科技行业的老香港人，带着妻子和四岁的女儿去看赛马。

;

;“这是她第一次观看，我们想向她展示什么是赛马，了解这项运动，”他说。 “上周四我也去看了沙田的比赛，这里的人潮看起来比较少。”

;

;主办方还设置了摊位游戏，奖品有冰淇淋。随着人潮增多，约十几名警察在该地区巡逻。

;

;旅游发展局主席彭耀佳博士表示，比赛是展示香港传统习俗和文化的机会

;

;“随着航班的恢复，越来越多的游客来到香港，他们渴望在购物和餐饮之外享受独特的体验，享受传统文化和习俗，我们相信“这些庆祝活动将来会吸引更多游客。”他说。

;

;香港中国龙舟协会秘书长钟志乐表示，他对世界龙舟锦标赛充满信心，由于现已解除疫情限制，今年的活动从香港移至泰国，将于 2027 年返回香港。这项活动每两年举办一次，将于 2025 年在德国举行。

;鸭脷洲新住宅首轮销售，售价更高与最近推出的其他项目相比，该项目在周六启动前几个小时突然被取消，因为香港开发商在预期的加息之前急于以较低的价格出售房屋。

;

;Aruna 项目由庄氏中国投资发展的项目，原计划提供25个单位，面积介乎205平方尺至317平方尺，折扣后售价介乎531万港元至858万港元（合109万美元），即每平方尺25,945港元至27,498港元，根据原始销售信息。

;

;创氏中国没有回应置评请求。该公寓楼的销售代理中原地产和美联物业均表示，开发商并未透露取消销售的原因。

;

;供应紧张，香港周末房屋销售下滑

;< p>;庄氏中国采取这一罕见举措之际，由于需求疲软和新房库存激增，香港开发商竞相以五年来未见的价格出售公寓。

;

;恒基兆业地产本周表示，启德恒利园提供首批148个单位，提供740个单位，折扣后平均尺价21,088港元。中原地产亚太区副主席陈永康表示，这比同区的剩余新房库存便宜 15%。

;

;一些开发商甚至通过抵押贷款折扣来吸引买家，

;

;Star Properties于3月向元朗After The Rain项目的前六名买家发放每张价值高达11,000港元的火车票，而Grand Ming Group则为向即将推出的土瓜湾开发项目 The Grands 的前六名买家每人发放价值 8,800 港元的代金券。

;

;香港开发商将新项目价格降至 2018 年水平，以促进销售

;< p>;房主们也纷纷打折出售自己的公寓。

;

;今年前5个月，大型房地产开发项目的二手交易中有10.2%是亏本出售的中原地产的数据显示，较2022年下半年上升约2个百分点。平均损失为 8%。

;

;一些房主一直在“抓住时机”出售自己的房产，因为继去年暴跌后，今年价格上涨，导致折扣交易增加。中原地产研究部高级副董事杨明仪。

;

;进一步加息的预期也给国内市场带来压力。

;

;中国一位母亲听到这句话后仰头大笑的故事她 23 岁的儿子获得了一份月薪 14,000 元人民币（2,000 美元）的实习机会，这一消息在大陆社交媒体上引起热议。

;

;这位来自中国东南部福建省的身份不明的女子对她的大女儿做出了反应据白鹿视频报道，吕姓女士透露，儿子将在船上工作。

;

;吕女士表示，当她的母亲告诉她这个消息时，她忍不住笑了。

;

; “我弟弟今年23岁，刚开始上船实习。”吕女士告诉白鹿视频。

;

;吕女士表示，哥哥一年8个月的月薪为14000元。必须在船上度过。

;

;一年中的其他四个月，他将没有报酬，但她说他可以在家里享受那段时光。

;

;“我妈妈觉得就像是意外的收获一样。她很高兴。”吕女士说。

;

;女儿说，妈妈把弟弟和自己抚养长大很不容易，但现在她已经完成学业搬出去了，弟弟也已经长大了。有了新工作，妈妈就可以安心退休了。

;

;“等他拿到第一份月薪后，妈妈就开始退休，享受晚年生活。”吕说。

;< p>;这个故事在中国媒体上疯传，很多人都对这位母亲的反应表示同情。

;

;有人说：“除了工作本身，她还很高兴她的儿子开始了独立的生活。”

;

;还有人评论道：“无论如何，一个能养活自己的应届毕业生，绝对是一件值得庆贺的事情。”

;

;中国本来就很高的青年失业率，近年来愈演愈烈。

;

;今年 4 月，《华盛顿邮报》报道称，今年夏天有 1158 万应届毕业生加入就业市场，而此时 16 至 24 岁年轻人的失业率已达到 20% 以上。

;

;在去年秋季的中国招聘季，大约 45% 的应届毕业生没有收到一份工作机会。

;这需要时间，但经过 28 个月的谈判，赞比亚开创了先例 -与中国和其他双边债权人达成协议，重组63亿美元贷款，其中欠中国41亿美元。

;

;赞比亚周四宣布，已与赞比亚就全面债务处理达成协议G20共同框架下的官方债权人，为这个铜资源丰富的国家提供了急需的金融喘息空间。

;

;赞比亚政府将其描述为“恢复赞比亚长期债务可持续性的重要一步”。< /p>;

;“但是艰苦的工作还没有结束，”赞比亚总统哈坎德·希奇莱马 (Hakainde Hichilema) 在推特上写道。

;

;“现在我们必须继续努力与我们的私人债权人找到解决方案，这样我们就可以专注于振兴我们的经济，为所有赞比亚人建设更光明的未来。

;

;“解决我们的债务负担将有助于吸引投资，从而创造就业机会并改善生计。”

;

;中国呼吁多边贷款机构缓解赞比亚债务负担

;

;自赞比亚成为2020年第一个因Covid-19而拖欠外债并申请债务减免的非洲国家以来，已经过去两年多了。

;

;该进程一再拖延，世界银行和国际货币基金组织（IMF）指责中国债务重组进展缓慢。

;

;根据新协议，中国作为赞比亚最大的双边贷款国-赞比亚的负担最大，同意重组总额中的 41 亿美元，其余部分由法国、英国、南非、以色列和印度提供。

;

;赞比亚没有获得债务减记，但官方债权人同意长期偿还债务。延长债务偿还期限。

;

;此外，赞比亚的债务重组期限将长达20年，其中有3年的宽限期。赞比亚还将寻求向私人债权人（包括债券持有人）寻求类似的待遇，这些债权人持有该国另外68亿美元的贷款。

;

;这些减记符合中国对债务重组而不是冲销的偏好。

;

;传统上，中国不会取消向其他国家提供的优惠贷款、信用额度或信用贷款。相反，它会延长还款期限或降低利率。即便如此，中国传统上会放弃无息贷款，这仅占中国向非洲国家提供的贷款总额的一小部分（约5%）。

;

;赞比亚财政部和国家规划部表示，这笔债务处理措施包括大幅延长期限和降低利率，这将允许将额外的财政资源分配给关键的公共投资，特别是在卫生、教育和基础设施发展方面。

;

;根据商定的条款，官方债权人将在国际货币基金组织支持的计划结束时根据赞比亚的债务承受能力提供债务处理。

;

;“该协议预计将为国际货币基金组织执行董事会批准第一次审查铺平道路赞比亚财政部表示：“我们将在未来几周内完成该基金支持的计划，从而允许支付国际货币基金组织下一批约 1.88 亿美元的融资。”

;

;但是，赞比亚必须满足一些条件，将根据国际货币基金组织和世界银行低收入国家债务可持续性框架进行评估。

;

;中国财团将在现金短缺的赞比亚修建6.5亿美元的收费公路

;

;债权人由中国和法国共同主持的委员会一致认为，如果情况改善到足以证明债务承载能力从“弱”升级为“中等”，则将调整债务处理，在这种情况下，本金偿还将加速，利息支付将增加.

;

;官方债权人与赞比亚政府达成一致，以当地货币计价的债务将被排除在任何待遇之外。

;

;领导人，包括法国总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙、美国财政部长珍妮特·耶伦和世界银行和国际货币基金组织负责人对这一决定表示欢迎。

;

;马克龙表示，该协议是一项“历史性成就”，债权人委员会“继续动员起来，确保陷入债务陷阱的其他国家从多边应对措施中受益” .

;

;撒哈拉以南非洲地缘经济分析师 Aly-Khan Satchu 表示，该协议对赞比亚来说是最佳结果，三年的宽限期给了它一些喘息的空间。

;

; Satchu 表示：“我们仍然需要了解该交易的细节，但债权人似乎通过降低利率和延长期限来避免减记。”

;

; Sat, 24 Jun 2023 16:50:01 +0800 Jail term for abuse case in China doesn’t go far enough, critics sayhttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/politics/article/3225139/jail-term-abuse-case-china-doesnt-go-far-enough-critics-say?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.24 16:00;
;;

;The case of a 26-year-old man who was jailed over the abuse and eventual suicide of his girlfriend in Beijing has stirred debate over whether Chinese law goes far enough to protect against domestic violence.

;

;Mou Linhan was sentenced on June 15 to three years and two months in prison for abusing his girlfriend, identified only by her surname Chen.

;

;The Haidian District People's Court in Beijing also ordered Mou to pay 730,000 yuan (US$101,700) in compensation to the victim's mother.

;

;The case is being seen by some as a step forward in the protection of women in China. But critics say the extent of the mental torture that Chen endured was not fully taken into account in the verdict.

;

;According to the court's judgment, Mou and Chen were both students at Peking University in Beijing and had lived together between September 2018 and October 2019. Chen took poison in a bid to end her life on October 9, 2019. She never recovered and died on April 11 the following year.

;

;The court accepted that Chen had endured verbal abuse from Mou over a long period and that the abusive treatment had resulted in Chen's mental health deteriorating and caused her to take her own life.

;

;“There is a criminal law causal link with the harmful consequences of the victim's death by suicide,” the court said in the judgment.

;

;Prosecutors had also accused Mou of inflicting physical violence on Chen, but the court found there was insufficient evidence to support that claim.

;

;Putting a price on 2 decades of full-time housework in China

;

;Chen's mother, whose full name was not disclosed, told Guangzhou-based South Reviews that she was disappointed with the sentence and would appeal.

;

;“The sentence is too short,” she told the magazine on June 15. “It's my daughter's life.”

;

;Mou has been in custody since his arrest in June 2020 and will be due for release in August, having served the full jail term.

;

;The case provoked a strong reaction in China when it was first reported by media, with Mou accused of degrading and abusing Chen, including for not being a virgin and by forcing her to take nude photos.

;

;According to state newspaper Legal Daily, the presiding judge in the case said the court had viewed Mou and Chen as being in a family relationship based on their cohabitation behaviour.

;

;That meant the case was treated as domestic violence. Under China's criminal law, the crime of abuse can only be applied when it involves people who are family members.

;

;Wang Keke, a partner at W&H Law Firm in Beijing, said it was a significant ruling for the protection of women in abusive relationships.

;

;“In this case, Mou and Chen lived together for a long time, so the definition of [what constitutes a] family member should be interpreted broadly,” Wang said.

;

;“This is conducive to protecting those who suffer violence in intimate relationships.”

;

;Chinese city targets domestic violence, but links it with anti-divorce efforts

;

;Some 30 per cent of married women in the 270 million households across China had experienced domestic violence as at the end of 2019, according to the All-China Women's Federation.

;

;China introduced its first domestic violence law in 2016, under which victims can apply for a personal protection order.

;

;People who experience violence while cohabiting can also apply for a personal protection order, according to a guidance against domestic violence issued by the Supreme People's Court on the same day as Mou's conviction.

;

;But the law does not clearly define psychological violence.

;

;Feng Yuan, co-founder of Equality, an advocacy group for women's rights and gender based in Beijing, said Mou's sentence did not go far enough and that he should have been punished for intentional injury.

;

;“One of the serious problems [with the judgment] is that the mental harm Chen suffered was ignored,” Feng said.

;

;That view was echoed by Zhou Xiaoxuan, a key figure in China's #MeToo movement. She said that while the sentence was an improvement on how such cases had been handled in the past, it was “hardly satisfactory”.

;

;“This will be a deterrent to those perpetrating psychological violence in intimate relationships,” Zhou said.

;

;“But the Mou case is not isolated. Women are more easily controlled in intimate relationships, and slut-shaming is common in China,” she said. “Gender-based violence is a structural problem, and the law is supposed to make progress when seeing it.”

; Sat, 24 Jun 2023 16:20:01 +0800 Hongkongers throw caution to the wind with political satire, puns in typhoon naming contest, as loaded entries flood social mediahttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/3225252/hongkongers-throw-caution-wind-political-satire-puns-typhoon-naming-contest-loaded-entries-flood?utm_source=rss_feed

;Hong Kong internet users flooded social media with puns and political innuendos for a typhoon naming contest by the city's weather forecaster, with one analyst calling the phenomenon a subtle form of satire from residents amid free speech concerns.

;

;The Observatory is soliciting names for tropical cyclones “with Hong Kong characteristics” that are easily pronounceable, bilingual and neither “discriminating [nor] controversial” to add to a list for consideration by an international body.

;

;Some suggestions in Chinese had gone viral on social media by Saturday, two days after the competition began. Among them were: “Glory”, alluding to a 2019 protest song the government recently sought to ban; “Pikachu”, playing on Chief Executive John Lee Ka-chiu's name; and “Improve”, which frequently appears on slogans by authorities about electoral reforms.

;

;Why Typhoon Mawar is sending mercury soaring, bringing haze in Hong Kong

;

;Hongkongers swiftly responded to the names on Facebook and LIHKG, a Reddit-like forum, with one joking: “The typhoon won't be allowed to enter Hong Kong if it's named 'Glory' because of a possible injunction!”

;

;Authorities are seeking a court ban on all forms of the protest song “Glory to Hong Kong” and its derivatives. A representative from the Department of Justice said the injunction was aimed at people who had the intention to incite secession, sedition, or to violate the national anthem law.

;

;Other popular names drawing hundreds of positive responses were “National Security” and “One Country, Two Systems”.

;

;Veteran commentator Sonny Lo Shiu-Hing called the naming suggestions “knee-jerk reactions”, indicating they were typical of a psychological response in societies undergoing political transformation and also a form of subtle participation in politics.

;

;He said the dominance of politics-themed names suggested that residents were trying to “make the most” of available channels to express themselves amid the city's overhauled governance, where some perceived free speech to be retreating.

;

;“Some people are still using available space on social media to express satire and cynical dissent,” Lo said. “These names reflect public opinion and political culture in some sectors.”

;

;Through the naming activity, the Observatory hopes to improve awareness and knowledge of the hazards brought about by tropical cyclones.

;

;A similar contest was last held in 2005, when names including “Tai Chi”, referring to the centuries-old Chinese martial art, and “Kapok”, a common flower-bearing tree, were selected from 25,000 entries.

;

;Hong Kong logs hottest day of year as temperature soars to 34.6 degrees at Observatory

;

;Participants can submit their suggestions on the forecaster's website from Thursday to the end of July. Shortlisted names will be made available for public voting online later in the year.

;

;The winning entries will be submitted to a typhoon committee operating under a United Nations body and the World Meteorological Organization for approval when a name needs to be replaced.

;

;The committee has approved names from the 14 members since 2000 for tropical cyclones in the Western North Pacific and the South China Sea.

;

;Names are retired when there are serious casualties and economic losses, requiring the member that proposed the name to provide a replacement.

;

;The current list has 10 names provided by Hong Kong, which includes “Ma-on” meaning horse saddle, “Dolphin” and “Lion Rock”, one of the city's peaks.

;

;Medical services disrupted amid Hong Kong's 1st amber rainstorm warning of the year

;

;The name “Kai-tak”, submitted by the city, has been retired while Ma-on is still pending a replacement despite it's use also being discontinued. The former, in 2017, led to 2.8 billion pesos (US$50.2 million) worth of damage, 47 deaths and 44 disappearances in the Philippines. The latter, which struck in 2022, was also requested by the Southeast Asian country to be decommissioned with three deaths and damage totalling about 2.4 billion pesos.

;

;In the 2005 contest, entries included the names of public figures and popular local delicacies. Some names were rejected by the typhoon committee because of negative connotations in other languages.

;

;“Quite a number of nominations used local Hong Kong food ... but a number of judges could not imagine a barbecued pork bun hitting other countries or Hong Kong,” said then observatory director Lam Chiu-ying at the time.

;China's education ministry has forecast that 11.58 million students will graduate this year, at the same time as unemployment rates for the 16-24 age group are at record highs – hitting 20.8 per cent in May, according to the National Bureau of Statistics.

;

;It is unclear how many graduates will be needed to replenish the PLA's two million-strong forces, as numbers mainly depend on how many soldiers and officers are coming up for retirement.

;

;According to data from military service units stationed at universities on the mainland, more than one million graduates have applied to join the PLA since 2017.

;

;Province rolls out 100-day plan to help China's anxious graduates 'land a job'

;

;Zhou Chenming, a researcher with the Beijing-based Yuan Wang military science and technology think tank, said recruiting more fresh graduates “would not only help Chinese local authorities to relieve the ongoing employment”.

;

;“The most important task of the PLA is to seize the opportunity to hunt more talent to help the military achieve its ultimate goal of military modernisation,” he said.

;

;Former PLA instructor Song Zhongping said joining the army had become a new norm for university students, with more of them turning to the military as an alternative platform to build a better career path amid the modernisation programme.

;

;“The PLA is now taking a volunteer system. More science and engineering talent joining the army would not only help the army achieve its goal of modernisation, but also pave the way for its future plan of military professionalisation,” he said.

;

;“Chinese secondary students were once the main source of the PLA, but such a trend has changed in recent years, and now only high-quality high school students would be picked for military academies as trainees and cadets.”

;

;China's PLA relaxes rules for non-combat, hi-tech troops. But there's a catch

;

;Last week, military newspaper PLA Daily reported that this year's academy enrolments would focus on science and technology majors “because of the needs and tasks for combat-readiness and war preparation training”.

;

;According to the report, the all-powerful Central Military Commission's training and administrative department intends for the army's 27 academies to recruit more than 17,000 high school students this year – 2,000 more than 2022 and an increase of 13 per cent.

;

;Students aged between 17 and 20 who achieve a first grade in college entrance examinations and have also passed basic physical and political reviews are qualified to apply, the PLA Daily said.

;

;The National University of Defence Technology at Changsha, in the central province of Hunan, and other military academies have started expanding and diversifying their intake “specifically in commanding and technical categories”, it said.

;

;China's military to refocus on R&D after decade-long hardware drive: analysts

;

;The PLA Daily said the expansion aims “to meet the demands of military modernisation that need more high-quality and specific military experts and professionals”.

;

;High school students have become a main source for the PLA's efforts to cultivate specific military talent, but the army is still finding it difficult to attract the country's most outstanding young people, according to Zhou from the Beijing-based think tank.

;

;“Compared with top public universities like Peking and Tsinghua, military academies are less attractive to outstanding high school students in the first-tier cities like Beijing and Shanghai,” Zhou said.

;

;This could be why the PLA schools prefer to target students from second and third-tier cities, where the vocational outlook is relatively weak, he added.

;

;The PLA is also prioritising the return of veterans with command and technical experience in its new rules for the recruitment of soldiers in wartime, released in April.

;

;While China has vowed to become a world-class military power on a par with the US by 2050, a more immediate goal is to achieve “a modern fighting force” by 2027 – the centenary of the PLA's founding during the civil war, which ended with Kuomintang forces fleeing to Taiwan.

;

;The island – which Beijing regards as part of its territory, to be brought under mainland control, by force if necessary – has become a potential flashpoint in the growing rivalry with Washington.

;

;Most countries, including the US, do not recognise Taiwan as an independent state. However, Washington opposes any attack on the self-ruled island and is committed to helping with Taipei's military defences.

;

;Since former president Donald Trump came to office in 2016, Washington has been steadily enhancing its military and economic ties – as well as unofficial diplomatic relations – with Taipei, to Beijing's fury.

;

;The policy has continued under Joe Biden's administration, leading to increasing tensions between Washington and Beijing, which views any attempt to promote independence for Taiwan – or its elevation on the world stage – as a red line.

;

;Former US House speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taipei in August sparked a dramatic increase in the PLA's military activity in the Taiwan Strait. Since then, there have been a number of confrontations in the region between the US and Chinese militaries.

;

;Beijing is also facing geopolitical challenges on other fronts like the South China Sea, and in the Himalayas, where it has a border dispute with India.
